items.biography:
Virology Research Journal is a peer-reviewed journal which covers all aspects of theoretical and practical research of viruses – sub microscopic, parasitic particles of genetic material contained in a protein coat– and virus-like agents. Virology Research Journal is an open access journal designed for the wide dissemination of research in this field to worldwide audience. New developments in methodology and techniques are important resources for the research community.

For any further queries please WhatsApp us at +44-7360-538437

E mail us at virus@theresearchpub.com

items.biography:
Contact Information:
•	Current Position: Postdoctoral Researcher
•	Department: Virology
•	Organization: Animal Health Research Institute, Agricultural Research Centre, Egypt.
•	Address: 4th kamal farid st., Bulak Aldakrour city, Giza province, Egypt
•	Mobile: 01111152239
•	Emails: Fieldagy_ahmed@yahoo.com, Fawzysahmed@gmail.com, Ahmed.Afify@ahri.gov.eg 
Education/Qualifications:
•	Bachelor of Veterinary Medical Sciences: Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, Cairo University, Egypt (2008)
Graduated in the top 5% of the class, demonstrating exceptional dedication to academic excellence
•	Master of Veterinary Medical Sciences (Virology): Department of Virology, Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, Cairo University, Egypt (2013).
Embarked on advanced studies in virology, building a strong foundation in this specialized field
•	PhD of Veterinary Medical Sciences (Virology): Department of Virology, Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, Cairo University, Egypt (2017)
Concluded an extensive doctoral program, advancing the understanding of viral diseases and diagnostics
Professional Experience:
•	Research Assistant (Jul. 2010 – Jan. 2014):
•	Joined the Department of Virology at the Animal Health Research Institute, Egypt, and contributed significantly to research on animal viral infections.
•	Assistant Researcher of Virology (Feb. 2014 – Jan. 2018):
•	Continued my academic journey by becoming an Assistant Researcher at the Department of Virology, Animal Health Research Institute, Egypt.
•	Researcher of Virology (Feb. 2018 – Present):
•	Currently serving as a Researcher in the Department of Virology, Animal Health Research Institute, Egypt
•	Responsibilities encompass a wide spectrum of tasks, including viral diagnosis, sero-prevalence studies, virus strains management, antiviral drug evaluation, fieldwork for specimen collection, and adherence to ISO 17025 Standards in collaboration with the Quality Team.
Academic/Training Experiences:
•	Trainer at Regional Training Sessions:
I've served as a trainer at multiple regional training sessions organized by the Arab Organization for Agricultural Development (AOAD), focusing on the survey, monitoring, diagnosis, and control of various viral diseases, including Foot and Mouth Disease (FMD) and Rift Valley Fever (RVF) in Egypt.
•	Training Courses and Workshops:
Actively participated in various training courses and workshops, enhancing expertise in advanced virological diagnostic techniques, biosafety, and laboratory management
List of Publications:
•	My contributions to several research papers in the field of virology have expanded scientific knowledge on topics such as Equine Arteritis Virus, Equine Herpesvirus, Foot and Mouth Disease, and more. These publications have added valuable insights to the global scientific community's understanding of viral diseases.
Research/Scholarly Activities:
•	My achievements include participation in the first isolation of FMD Sat-2 in Egypt, contributing to the detection of emerging viral strains, and developing novel diagnostic tools such as ELISA kits for EHV antigen detection. These accomplishments have significantly impacted the field of veterinary virology in Egypt and beyond.
Community Services:
•	I have provided hands-on experiences to others in the diagnosis of viral infections and various laboratory techniques. This transfer of knowledge and skills has contributed to the professional development of fellow researchers and veterinarians.
Professional Membership:
•	I hold memberships in prestigious organizations related to veterinary science and virology, including the International Veterinary Vaccinology Network (IVVN), Egyptian Veterinary Syndicate, Egyptian Society of Virology (ESV), Egyptian Society of Biosafety (EGBSA), Egyptian Society of Immunologists, The Egyptian Veterinary Association of Epidemiology, Scientific Society of AHRI, and the International Nano-science Community.
Journals Reviewer:
•	I have served as a reviewer for reputable journals, including Hosts and Viruses, Advances in Animal and Veterinary Sciences, PloS One, and Tropical Animal Health and Production. My role as a reviewer has contributed to the rigorous assessment of scientific research in the field.
Medical Laboratory Scientist( Virology) MSc Medical Microbiology,  PhD Medical Microbiology and Parasitology (Virology) in view

In 1991 is graduated from Iv. Javakhishvili Tbilisi State University, specializing in microbiology and still works as a senior researcher at the G. Eliava Institute of Bacteriophage, Microbiology and Virology in the Department of Strains and Phage Collection. In 2006, she defended his doctoral thesis on the topic - "Study of the biological properties of Pseudomonas phages". Since 2016 she combines this with working as a head of the Biological Control Group at the same institute. Dr. Suladze is a member of GAGAM and one of the founders of the association the Eliava Foundation. She has long term experience of working on standardization of phage preparations for the diagnosis of different Pseudomonas spp. and Enterobacteriacae species, as well as she also has experience working on Yersinia spp., Burkholderia spp.  and their respective phages. Dr. Suladze participated trainings related to her professional work (writing grants, working with biological pathogens, biosafety, biodefense, bioethics, cyber-safety, working in a BLS level 3 laboratory, etc.), both in Georgia and abroad. She is a participant in 12 international grant projects. She participated in various international conferences. Has published more than 60 scientific works (scientific articles and theses in collections of materials of international conferences). Several bachelor's theses have been completed under her guidance. Since 2012 she has been teaching microbiology courses at Tbilisi State University and Georgian American University.

items.biography:
Graduated with honors in Medical Biotechnology in 2016, I specialized in the field of immunology with a particular focus on HLA typing for the diagnosis of HLA-associated diseases and patient-donor compatibility for stem cell transplants. During my study and work experience, I acquired advanced skills in molecular biology techniques such as SSP-PCR, SSO-PCR Luminex, Sanger sequencing, and NGS with ION Torrent.
In 2018, I obtained a scholarship at the national reference laboratory for foodborne viruses,Department of Food Safety, Nutrition and Veterinary public health, Unit of Microbiological Safety and Foodborne Diseases, Italian National Institute of Health, focusing on the research of foodborne viruses through molecular methods for virus concentration from different food matrices, nucleic acid extraction, viral typing, as well as cell biology techniques for viral titration and viral load determination.
In 2019, I won a starting grant for the research project called “Bovine Meat and Milk Factors (BMMFs): a new foodborne threat?”  and in 2021, I started a PhD in Animal Health and Zoonosis. 
In 2023, I secured a fixed-term contract at the Italian National Institute of Health, focusing on biosafety issues in BSL-3 laboratories, and in 2024, I won a permanent position through a competition. My experience and unwavering dedication have allowed me to develop in-depth skills in the field of foodborne viral issues and scientific research.

Prof. dr hab. Agnieszka Szuster-Ciesielska is a researcher at the Department of Virology and Immunology Institute of Biological Sciences of Maria Curie-Skłodowska University in Lublin. He is also the Deputy Director of the Institute of Biological Sciences. She is a biologist specializing in virology and immunology with 30 years of research and teaching experience. During a scientific internship at Stanford University School of Medicine, Department of Microbiology and Immunology in 2013, she expanded her competencies in the field of virology by working in a group dealing with the study of Hepatitis C and Dengue viruses. Prof. Szuster-Ciesielska is currently the coordinator of the National Science Center project on the development of asthma after inhalation of microscopic phytopathogenic fungi. She is the author of over 160 papers in virology and immunology,  including over 70 original peer-reviewed articles published in reputed journals. Her publications have been cited over 1,800 times. Prof. Szuster-Ciesielska is a recognized popularizer of knowledge in virology, human immunology, and vaccinology. For her popularizing activity in this field, she was awarded the „Knowledge Promoter” title by the "Puls Medycyny" magazine. She was included in the list of the 100 most influential people in Polish medicine and the health care system for 2021 and 2022.

Associate Professor of the Department of Microbiology, Virology, Immunology of the Tashkent Medical Academy
LABOR ACTIVITY

2019 - h.v - assistant professor of microbiology department of Tashkent Medical Academy, director of master's course "Bacteriology and virology"

Nandi Jayashree Seema (Bio-sketch)
jseemanandi@gmail.com
I am interested in discovering new avenues to mitigate infectious and inflammatory human
diseases impacting human health globally.
ORCID: 0000-0001-6325-6693
Citations 427, h-index 10 (based on 'Researchgate')

Invited talk:
• ASV 2023 Abstract entitled 'Epigenetics, viral latency and Unintegrated HIV-1DNA',
selected for oral presentation at the forth coming ASV annual meeting to be held in
University of Georgia, The Classic Center, Athens, GA.
• ASV Global Scholar Award talk Jul 17, 2022, Epizootic infection by HPH5N! AIV of
migratory cranes. (USA)
• ASV Global Scholar Award Virtual talk May 2021 Bidirectional Transmission of
infectious viruses at human-animal interface. (USA)
• H5N1 AIV infecting wild migratory cranes, March 2022 at Research Laboratory,
Central India Institute of Medical Sciences (CIIMS), 88/2, Bajaj Nagar, Nagpur,
440010 (India).
• Tulane National Primate Center, Covington, Louisiana May 2012 Novel Simian Type
D Retrovirus SRV-6 infecting wild Indian langurs. (USA)
• Sole Author of a Reference book 'Zoonotic viral infection: a global perspective' to be
published in 2023 by Elsevier.
Skills
• Abreast with current literature in Immunology, Virology, (Retroviruses, Lentiviruses
and Influenza virus), and zoonoses of infectious viral diseases.
• A team player and keen learner
• Highly motivated with excellent communication skills in English, oral and written.
• Skilled in laboratory techniques with meticulous attention to details (Biochemistry,
Molecular biology, Virology, Immunology and Cell biology).
• Proficient in automated Sanger sequencing, genomic data analyses by Standard
bioinformatics tools (DNASTAR, MEGA, Clustal W), phylogenetic analyses of viral and
host genomes.
• Excellent teaching skills. Taught and mentored Ph.D. students in Virology at the
Savitribai Phule Pune University: SPPU (formerly Pune University), India from 1990-
2002. Courses taught at the Pune University, India: Ph.D. (Microbiology,
Biochemistry), M.Sc. (Microbiology), M.Sc. (Biochemistry), Summer course in
Virology for students from different Indian Universities.
• Examiner for Ph.D. and M.Sc. programs of other Indian Universities.
• Published in peer reviewed journals as first and corresponding author.
• Presentations: Invited as participant, speaker and chairperson at International
Conferences on HIV and emerging diseases.
• Edited and reviewed research articles submitted by peers on infection by HIV-1 and
retroviruses to World Journal of AIDS, and Emerging Infectious Diseases (EID), CDC,
USA.
• Reviewed HIV-1 related grant applications at Study Sections, NIH, Bethesda, MD,
USA (RFA-HL-04-031, 2005).
Publications
• Epizootic, Endemic and Pandemic Zoonotic Viral Infections of migratory cranes.
Shravan Singh Rathore, Hem Singh Gehlot, Gyan Prakash, Jayashree S. Nandi*
Journal of Biosciences and Medicines Vol.10 No.3, March 10, 2022
DOI: 10.4236/jbm.2022.103010, Highly accessed, 69 Downloads 602 Views

setting at human-animal interface. Current Research in Virological Sciences,

items.biography:
Emma Muzaffar kizi Aghayeva graduated from the Azerbaijan Agricultural Institute in 1974 with honors. In 1975, he was enrolled in the postgraduate study at the General Virology Laboratory of the Institute of Virology, and continued his postgraduate studies at the Moscow Institute of Experimental Veterinary in "Microbiology, Virology and Immunology". In 1981 he successfully defended his thesis on "Immunochemical capsular capsule antigen and serologic type Pasteurella multocida" and successfully defended his thesis on microbiology, virology, epizootology, mycology and immunology. In 1984, the All-Union developed a methodological recommendation "On the characterization of microorganisms and the acquisition of typospecific serum". In 1982 he was elected as an assistant at the Department of Microbiology, Virology and Immunology of Az.KTA In 2000 he defended his doctoral thesis on microbiology, immunology, virology and mycology in Baku and received a doctorate in veterinary science.
Emma Agayeva was elected Associate Professor at the Department of Medical Biology and Genetics of the Azerbaijan Medical University in 2003 and has been working as a Professor in the Department of Medical Microbiology and Immunology at the Azerbaijan Medical University since January 2004. Mrs. Emma successfully carries out her scientific and pedagogical activity in the department and successfully heads the relevant dissertation works.
The main scientific interests of Ema Agayeva are microbiology, molecular biology, immunology, immunogenetics, biotechnology. His main scientific direction in the field of microbiology is related to the development of methods of diagnostics, treatment and prevention of infectious diseases of humans and agricultural animals.
Emma Agayeva has published and issued instructions for molecular diagnostics of avian influenza and Newcastle disease to all regions of Azerbaijan. He developed and introduced the stimulant NER, an immunomodulator in the field of immunology.
Mrs. Emma is currently conducting research in the Republic on the monitoring of antibiotic resistant strains of microorganisms, the originators of infectious diseases, the microbicidal effects of herbs extracted from plants and their application in medicine. He has received two (2) patents as a result of his research.
Agayeva is a full member of the European Society of Clinical Microbiologists and Infectious Diseases (ESCMID). He is also a member of the Azerbaijan Public Association of Medical Microbiologists and Immunologists.
Emma Agayeva has written over 170 scientific works, including several textbooks, monographs and methodical recommendations. It should be noted that Professor Emma Agayeva first published the textbook "Biotechnology and Genetic Engineering" in Azerbaijan, published in Azerbaijani and Russian languages, and presented it to students and young professionals. He has also published books on Veterinary Virology, Glossary of Terms in Microbiology, Immunology, Biotechnology and Genetic Engineering in Azerbaijani, Russian and English.
Emma Agayeva was a member of the Academic Council of the Faculty of Public Health at ATU and was a member of the University Trade Union Organization (2007-2017). He is currently a member of the Dissertation Council FD.03.014 on Microbiology, Immunology, Epidemiology and Hygiene at ATU and chair of the ATU's Microbiology, Immunology, Epidemiology and Infectious Disease Commission.
It should be noted that Emma Agayeva works as a highly qualified specialist in her position. Takes part in all scientific and pedagogical activities of the university, faculty, department and does not waste his ability to properly address the issues discussed. Ms. Emma has great respect for faculty, faculty and university staff, as well as students.
Taking into consideration these qualities, in 2011, the President of the Republic of Azerbaijan Emma Muzaffar was awarded the honorary title of "Honored teacher of Azerbaijan".
During her tenure, Emma has shown herself to be a competent researcher, publicist, and colleague in matters related to teaching and research as a member of the teaching and methodological committee of the department.
Emma Agayeva manages the scientific work of a large number of students through the department's Student Scientific Society. Emma Agayeva's performances at the annual Student Scientific Society conferences were highly appreciated and awarded by I and II degrees.

affiliations.department: Department of Medical Microbiology and Immunology

items.biography: Zhilinskaya Irina Nikolaevna, born in 1946, graduated in 1969 from Leningrad State University majoring in biochemistry, a teacher of biology and chemistry with a nominal scholarship named after Komarova. In 1973, graduated as a post-graduate student at the Research Institute of Influenza, in 1974 she defended her PhD thesis in virology, and in 2003 - a doctorate in virology. To the present works as leading researcher at the Research Institute of Influenza. Author of more than 100 published works, 3 patents, 3 monographs. Organizer and curator of postgraduate advanced training courses in virology, compiler of postgraduate advanced training programs in virology and training programs in residency in virology. Chairman of the dissertation council (D001.043.01) in virology, member of the certification committee of graduate students and residents of the Research Institute of Influenza, member of the expert group for the specialty "Virology" at the departmental certification commission of the Federal Biomedical Agency of the Russian Federation

I am a junior medical scientist in the Emerging Viral Threats, One Health Surveillance and Vaccines (EViTOH) division within the Infectious Disease and Oncology Research Institute (IDORI) at the University of the Witwatersrand. I specialise in virology, One Health, and arboviruses. I hold a BSc in Genetics and Microbiology and a BMedSc (Hons) in Medical Microbiology and Virology from the University of the Free State, as well as an MSc in Medical Virology from the University of Pretoria.

My research primarily focuses on orthobunyaviruses, with a particular interest in their detection in humans and animals within a One Health framework. I also contribute to the SARS-CoV-2 project, where SARS-CoV-2 has been detected in humans, wildlife, and rodents. My primary role involves performing functional assays to assess the neutralisation of SARS-CoV-2 variants using whole virus isolates from different pandemic waves and vaccinated patients. Additionally, I assist with full genome sequencing of arboviruses and SARS-CoV-2.

My work led to the first detection of Shamonda virus in an animal in South Africa. I have received the Van Rensburg/Lancet Pathology Laboratory Prize for the best BMedSc (Hons) student in pathology and the Van Rensburg/Lancet Pathology Floating Trophy for excellence across all pathology disciplines at the University of the Free State.

affiliations.department: Emerging Viral Threats, One Health Surveillance and Vaccines (EViTOH) division, Infectious Disease and Oncology Research Institute (IDORI)

items.biography: Graduated in Biomedicine from the University of Amazônia (2019), with a qualification in Clinical Analysis (2019), Specialization in Imaging (2022) and Technical Course in Radiology from the Centro Educacional Tecnológico da Amazônia (2023). Master in Virology from the Postgraduate Program in Virology at the Evandro Chagas Institute (2024). She is currently a PhD student in Virology at the Postgraduate Program in Virology at the Evandro Chagas Institute and a research fellow at the Foundation for Scientific and Technological Development in Health (FIOTEC) for the project Improving Surveillance Actions, Research in Public and Environmental Health (DIREX-003-FIO-24) working in the Serology Laboratory I of the Arbovirology and Hemorrhagic Fevers Section - SAARB/IEC/SVSA/MS. He has experience in arboviruses of importance to public health, neuroinvasive arboviruses, serological diagnosis for arboviruses and Oropouche virus (VORO).

affiliations.institution_name: Edward Via College of Osteopathic Medicine

items.biography:
Dr. El-Araby is a distinguished researcher currently working at the Molecular Biology and Biotechnology Unit of the Agriculture Research Center, specializing in molecular plant virology. He obtained his PhD in microbiology from Ain Shams University in 2024, where his doctoral research focused on the molecular and biological characterization of the tomato chlorosis virus, with an emphasis on utilizing nanotechnology for its management.
Prior to his doctoral studies, Dr. El-Araby completed his master's thesis at Sadat City University, where he developed and standardized rapid molecular biology-based techniques for the detection of several potato viruses within the Plant Biotechnology Department. His training at the Research Institute of HAAS Harbin in China further enhanced his expertise, particularly in seed potato multiplication and integrated disease control methods for producing virus-free seedlings.
As a principal investigator, Dr. El-Araby has successfully secured research grants funded by Saudi Arabia and has led numerous investigations in viral diagnostics, gene expression, and molecular virology. His contributions have been recognized through multiple submissions to GenBank, as well as numerous scientific publications and presentations at both national and international conferences.
Dr. El-Araby's current research interests are concentrated in three key areas:
Molecular Virology and Biotechnology
Protein-Protein Interaction and Prediction
Viral Control
Through his work, Dr. El-Araby aims to advance the understanding and management of plant viruses, contributing significantly to the field of molecular plant virology

keywords: Soil microbiology, Molecular ecolog, Biotechnology, Biochemistry, Phytopathology

items.biography: I am a Medical Scientist and Virologist with expertise in molecular biology, Virology and emerging and reemerging zoonotic viruses. I am currently a Junior Medical Scientist at the Emerging Viral Threats, One Health surveillance and vaccines (EViTOH) division within the Infectious Disease and Oncology Research Institute (IDORI) at the WITS Health Consortium. My research focuses on One Health investigations and diagnostics of arboviral and respiratory viruses in animals and humans. I have extensive experience within the laboratory environment and bio-safety as well as sample collection in the field where I am currently involved with rodent capture and harvesting tissue samples for research. I hold a B.Sc. in Environmental and Biological Sciences from the North-West University, a B.Med.Sc. Honours in Medical Microbiology and Virology and M.Med.Sc. with specialisation in Virology from the University of the Free State. I have also co-authored publications in high impact peer reviewed journals. I enjoy being innovative and finding solutions to problems within the research and laboratory environment. Through my research, I strive to contribute to the welfare of his community and South Africa by furthering science and healthcare and taking part in strategies aimed at monitoring and controlling the spread of disease.

affiliations.department: Infectious Diseases and Oncology Research Institute (IDORI)

items.biography: Karabo Salemane is a Virologist with a focus on virus discovery, One Health, and the surveillance and molecular characterisation of enteric and respiratory viruses in wastewater and surface water. She holds a BSc in Chemistry and Microbiology and a BMedSc (Hons) in Medical Microbiology and Virology from the University of the Free State. Additionally, she has completed her MSc in Medical Virology, with distinction, from the University of Pretoria. Karabo has contributed to numerous research projects. She has authored the first comprehensive study of hepatitis E virus (HEV) in South African water systems. Currently employed as a Junior Medical Scientist at the Emerging Viral Threats, One Health surveillance and vaccines (EViTOH) division within the Infectious disease and oncology research institute (IDORI) at the University of Witwatersrand, her research focuses on wastewater-based epidemiological investigations in South Africa. Overall, she is dedicated to advancing our understanding of the role of viruses in human health and the environment, and to utilising this knowledge to improve public health and well-being.

Gospava Lazić, PhD Biology
Graduated at the Faculty of Sciences, Department of Biology and Ecology, University of Novi Sad, 2009. BSc thesis: Isolation and identification of animal herpesviruses in cell culture. Master thesis, Faculty of Sciences, Department of Biology and Ecology, University of Novi Sad, 2011. Doctoral dissertation, Faculty of Sciences, Department of Biology and Ecology, University of Novi Sad, 2011-2016, PhD thesis: “Presence and prevalence of animal and human viruses in surface water in Vojvodina Province”.

Scientific titles:
- 2022 Senior Research Associate
- 2017 Research Associate
- 2014 Research Assistant
- 2011 Research Trainee 

Scientific and Research Work:
-	Basic Research interest:
Veterinary virology, food and environmental virology, vector-borne infections.
-	Main working and research activities:
detection of animal viral diseases by classical laboratory methods (ELISA, IH, VN);
detection of animal viral diseases by molecular diagnostic tests (PCR, RT-PCR, real-time PCR);
detection of viruses in environment (environmental virology), in vectors and in wild animals, 
molecular characterization of the viruses detected in animals, vectors and environment.

Professional Experience:
- Since 2018 – Deputy of head for departments of epizootiology, Clinical diagnostics, pathology and laboratory testing, Scientific Veterinary Institute “Novi Sad”, Novi Sad
- Since 2017 Head of the department for management for medical animal waste, Scientific Veterinary Institute “Novi Sad”, Novi Sad

items.biography:
My researches have been focusing on the fundamental investigation of parvoviruses, including infection, viral-host interaction and pathogenicity mechanism. The main scientific contributions including identification of AXL as a co-receptor for B19V infection of human erythroid progenitors, the identification of key viral proteins’ functions during human parvovirus B19 (B19V) entry, the establishment of a high-throughput screening platform for B19V and the screening of antiviral compounds, the elucidation of the replication mechanisms of Adeno-associated virus (AAV), mapping of the replication initiation complex and essential proteins in Human bocavirus 1 (HBoV1) replication center, and identification of the causative agent of short beak and dwarfism syndrome in Pekin ducks and elucidation of its epidemiology and pathogenic mechanism. These findings have expanded the understanding of parvoviruses infection and pathogenicity mechanism and provided scientific information for parvoviruses control and optimization of manufacturing processes of gene therapy products.

(I-A) Identification of viral and host protein interaction of B19V.	
Based on the endonuclease activity of B19V NS1 protein, I established a high-throughput screening platform for B19V and identified four leading antiviral compounds (Journal of Virology, 2021). I demonstrated the N-terminal domain of B19V VP1 enters human erythroid progenitors and inhibits B19 infection (Journal of Virology, 2021). I identified host protein AXL as a co-receptor for B19V infection of human erythroid progenitors (Science Advances, 2023).

(I-B) Dissection of HBoV1 replication initiation complex.
Combine with the established in vitro replication platform, I dissected the formation of HBoV1 replication initiation complex, which revealed the interaction of viral NS1 (Journal of Virology, 2022) and NP1 proteins with host proteins Ku complex, RPA complex (PLoS Pathogens, 2022), and CPSF6 (Journal of Virology, 2020). Besides, I helped to demonstrate that hairpin transfer-independent parvovirus DNA replication produces infectious virus, which is highlighted by editor (Journal of Virology, 2021).

(I-C) Function of DNA damage response in AAV and recombinant AAV (rAAV).
I reported the role of induced DDR in AAV replication and rAAV transduction (mBio, 2023). I found that inhibition of DNA-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit boosts rAAV transduction of polarized human airway epithelium (Molecular therapy. Methods & clinical development, 2023). These results have broadened the understanding of DDR in AAV replication and rAAV transduction. 

(I-D) investigation on goose parvovirus (GPV) and discovery of waterfowl associated virus.
My research revealed the genetic detection, characterization, and pathogenicity of GPV, which is the causative agent of short beak and dwarfism syndrome of Pekin ducks. I demonstrated the epidemiology and pathogenicity of this Pekin duck-origin GPV in goose embryos, goslings (Avian Pathology, 2018), and Cherry Valley Pekin ducks (Veterinary Microbiology, 2017; Infection, Genetics and Evolution, 2017), which benefits the duck industry. Besides, I helped to explore the genetic characterization of various novel viruses, e.g., astrovirus (Archives of Virology, 2018), megriviruses (Journal of General Virology, 2017), reovirus (Virus Research, 2016), and picornavirus (Journal of General Virology, 2014) in waterfowl. I participated in the generation of a reliable full-length cDNA of infectious Tembusu virus by using a PCR-based protocol (Virus Research, 2016). These results expanded our understanding of pathogenic viruses in waterfowl.

(I-E) Works on SARS-CoV2 and Bourbon virus.
I participated in the project to demonstrate the replication of SARS-CoV2 in human airway epithelium (mBio, 2020; Journal of Medical Virology, 2023) and establish a replicon reporter system of the emerging tick-borne Bourbon virus (Frontiers in Microbiology, 2020).
BSc. Biology. Researcher working  with Virology, Developmental Biology and (Stem) Cell Therapy @ UFRGS & HCPA. Fascinated with the huge impacts of such small things.

items.biography:
Nahla Mohamed, is a Sudanese & Swedish female, virologist and an associate Professor of Clinical Virology, I have more than 43 published articles in high impact scientific journals, expertise in viral diagnostics research, such as. 
1-Bioinformatics: Improving diagnostic methods for clinical microbiology, 
2- Method development: Nucleic acid and Antibody based methods for detection of infection Clinical Virology: 
3-Quality control, management of routine.  
4- I have deep and solid experience in: Next generation sequencing (NGS, Illumina technology) based Proximity Extension Assay (PEA) for proteomic analysis based on high-throughput, multiplex immunoassays of proteins using minimal volumes of serum, plasma, or almost any other type of biological sample, process DNA purification, DNA library preparation and NGS, QC and documentation of the workflow by LIMS according to SOPs standards. 
5- Experiences to data analysis and use others methodical approach to problem-solving and to refer to epidemiological data to get a better understanding the epidemiological dynamics of the diseases at the population level.
6- I am a member of several committees such as IRB, quality assurance and accreditation for medical curriculum, I am very interested and positive person, i did the best to fulfill the projects goals, and succeeded in doing. I am a very enthusiastic, active, and eager to learn. 
7- A broad experienced in the development and performance of clinically useful real-time PCRs and molecular tools in clinical virology aspects.

items.biography:
DR. MUHAMMAD IDREES; MERITORIOUS PROFESSOR
Prof. Idrees obtained his Ph. D. in Molecular Biology/Virology and then worked for his post-doctoral research at Division of Viral Hepatitis, Coordinating Centre for Infectious Diseases, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta USA. As recognition of tremendous contribution in the field of Molecular Biology/Virology, The Royal College of Pathologists London-UK awarded him with Fellowship of the College in 2015 upon the recommendation of Exam Committee and College Council. Dr. Idrees currently holds a senior faculty position of Meritorious Professor (BPS-22) at the Centre of Excellence in Molecular Biology (CEMB). Prof. Idrees has been affiliated with CEMB and the Centre for Applied Molecular Biology (CAMB), University of the Punjab, for over 25 years. During this time, he has held positions ranging from Research Officer to Professor and Director. He also served as Vice Chancellor of Hazara University from July 28, 2016, to July 28, 2019, and most recently led the University of Peshawar as its 24th Vice Chancellor from December 12, 2020, to December 11, 2023.
Dr. Idrees has over 25 years of extensive experience in academics, research, administration, and financial management. Early in his career, Prof. Idrees established a cutting-edge PCR-based diagnostic laboratory at CAMB, providing accessible and accurate diagnostics for infectious and genetic diseases. This initiative not only generated over Rs. 500 million in revenue but also spearheaded the development of indigenous molecular diagnostic kits for diseases such as HBV, HCV, M. tuberculosis, dengue, and SARS-CoV-2. His team performed more than 40,000 free PCR tests for hepatitis patients under the PM’s Hepatitis Prevention Program, delivering services valued at over Rs. 113 million. Additionally, he founded a state-of-the-art Molecular Virology Division at CEMB, significantly advancing scientific and clinical research through modern molecular techniques. He has been a member of various university Senates, Syndicates, Academic Councils, and other academic bodies, serving in leadership roles such as Chairman and Convener. His contributions extend to the development of molecular diagnostics facilities, research programs, and modern academic disciplines, making significant impacts in virology and public health. His scientific interests lie in basic and applied research using advanced molecular techniques. He established a state-of-the-art Molecular Virology Division at a public university and has authored more than 260 research papers in national and international journals, with an overall impact factor exceeding 1018 and citations surpassing 8,000. He also serves as an editor for several international scientific journals and has successfully mobilized funding worth over Rs. 3 billion from national and international agencies.
Prof. Idrees has been instrumental in restructuring organizations and launching academic programs. In 2015, he played a pivotal role in developing internationally acclaimed teaching and research initiatives in Applied Molecular Biology and Forensic Sciences. At Hazara University, he spearheaded the approval and launch of ten market-oriented academic disciplines. His contributions have been recognized with numerous accolades, including the TWAS "Best Young Scientist of the Year Award in Biology" (2009), the PAS Gold Medal in Emerging Technologies (2017), and the PCST Research Productivity Awards (2011–2017). Most recently, he received the Academic Excellence Awards from the APSUP in 2022 and 2023 for his exceptional contributions to academia and higher education in Pakistan. He has contributed to the development of guidelines for managing viral diseases and has played key roles in national quality assurance and accreditation processes. Dr. Idrees’s international engagements include collaboration with leading researchers and institutions, participation in global scientific events, and extensive training in leadership and governance. His achievements in institutional financial management and developmental projects have set benchmarks in the higher education sector. Through his tireless efforts, he continues to advance the fields of molecular biology and virology while contributing to the broader landscape of higher education and research in Pakistan.

Dr. Long was trained as a virologist in Wuhan Institute of Virology and Wageningen University and Research center. After gaining Ph.D, as postdoc researcher, he joined Professor Ralf Bartenschlager's team at molecular virology department in Heidelberg University, Germany. From 2013-2022, he led a research unit studying flavivirus assembly and host. From 2022, he was recruited by Fudan University to study medical viruses, with special interest in medical virus infection modified extracellular vesicles and  their functions.
